title: European Research and Technology Organisations and the Challenges of Sustainability and Competitiveness
segmentation: So first, the Arthur abbreviation comes out for the European Association of Research and Technology Organizations as they are to proudly says they promote the interests of over 300 research institutes in Europe.
And speaking about research and technology organizations, I would like to inform you that this term an abbreviation RTO in the future will be changed in the near future.
Do.
RPO.
So T will be lost.
And they will become research performing organizations.
Personally, I'm not very happy about the losing of tea, but there is a strong argument for that.
First is that in different countries, research and technology organizations are defined by different ways.
Therefore, artios are very different institutes.
Second, not only those who do research and technology in the way which we consider is being done by we, TTN or Fraunhofer.
They do it in a little bit different ways as in case of Yogev, Steven or Rueger.
Your name is in this POV closer to witty TT.
Annoying particular for good reasons.
So research performing should stress that we do something.
We perform research and we are the carriers of research as organized.
Nations with these 300 research institutions we do have, for example, as a single entity, entire Fraunhofer.
So this 300 are very respective research power in Europe among the members from Austria we do have one of the strongest pillars.
Your name research here present as our friend and partners.
Croatia and Slovenia, jointly independent from each other, but on the same day joint heir to represented by Roger Boscovich from Slovenia and Georgia Steven from Croatia.
In a very nice and friendly atmosphere, and one thing I think that deserves your attention is some information about facts and figures.
These institutions you see listed here they represent more than 80% of the target oriented research or applied research or contract research, which is not the same in the region.
Of Adria Alpa Pannonia.
So just this institutions are the major research power.
The others are universities, but they are not oriented in this direction as well as we are.
Second thing, these institutions have close to 3000 researchers.
So it's enormous power which should be well coordinated and trying to interact for the benefit of the region and all.
One of the interactions we have had very recently also collaborating with the Ortho was a conference held in autumn on the new materials in industry and medicine.
And this new method.
Cereals in industry and medicine is actually a part of the art of technical Special Interest Group.
Namely, Arthur made an experiment as they declare in the auto news, launching an experiment with technical special interest groups.
So they want to define which of the promising topics artios themselves find should be of interest.
And the first proposal came from our side on new materials.
That means material Sciences, and we organized the conference recently from each, several collaborations were already initiated.
A Arthur is a bottom up system.
Therefore it's not a problem to promote any priority you find interesting.
You only have to do it through your formal representative in the art board.
He also had recent meeting.
Annual general meeting in Paris and I put the photo of Eiffel Tower to show one of the nicest examples how the projects in high tech could be important.
As you know very well.
Nobody liked the idea of Eiffel Tower.
People consider it useless, embarrassing and it it will not stand.
It's a dangerous and nobody would be interested in such an ugly building, so just this tower has the income from tourism bigger than the most of the European countries.
Yep.
It is.
It is they in, in per year the value of the visitors is between 8 to 10 millions.
Millions people per year.
Go to the Eiffel Tower.
And it works still with the same engine.
With the same engineers.

So the the rest of my talk I will based on the talk that Chris Hall has given on Perrin Paris and I use some of his slides because a Arthur is not only bottom up system, but it's very transparent system so you could find easily his PowerPoint on the form of PDF online.
And that's exactly what I did today when I was asked to prepare my lecture.
So I took some of his slides and modify them slightly.
The key points of the meeting of the Arthur General Assembly few weeks ago in Paris was does Framework program work?
Is it sufficient enough as we want to do it and do we have a perspective in FP8?
And that's what.
The Task force of Arthur has trying to deal with.
So first is the fact that more than 20 years already, we do have one of the impulsion reasons why the European Union was funded.

Saying that the community shall have the objective of strengthening the scientific and technological basis of Community industry and encouraging it to become more competitive and international level while promoting all the research activities deemed necessary by virtue of other chapters of this Treaty.
This important rational.
Is the base for the competitiveness ideas of the Commission and the framework and requires clearly a policy support which unfortunately, is not always sufficient.
Development of the framework from FP52FP7.
Wolves in a way, as did Chris Hall say.
A consequence of uncoordinated motivations with unanticipated consequences.
So I think you would enjoy much more if Chris Hall himself would say that today, but I'm sure he would say that today.
The point of the idea is that some of the programs which appeared politically to be very promising, such as networks of excellence, is actually ended in an end road.
Second, there have been ad hoc interventions.

Surprisingly, such as European Research Council etc which put all together, let the task group of Arthur to conclude that the frameworks are building the academic star scientists, either junior or senior stars.
But just pop stars as a scientist and this is not what the society expects.
Therefore, Airto will propose.
European Strategic Technological Applied Research Council as appendant to the European Research Council.
We should have a strong input.
To overcome the gap we have in the fields of technology and the links between research institutions and industry.
Because this links by the framework have not been strengthened, On the contrary.
And this.
Research should build up what already was going on in practicing the art of strategic alliances.
You are all witnesses today of 1 strategic alliance being built by the research institutes from most reoperations Slovenia.
We have other friends and your name already has strategic alliances with other institutes quite effectively.
Institutes from France and Germany open your own research.
Units in France.
There is a strategic alliance between Finnish research Institutes and Germans, Dutch and Sweden, Swedish.
The point is that none of us is strong enough to do everything.
But when we find a particular topic of interest, then the research institutes could react fast.
So this trend of strategic alliances is supposed to bring the spinoff institutes or research units to support the industry when it's needed.

What I learned on the outer meeting was that there would be no European automotive industry without artios because the representatives of industry there said they would never have time and money to invest in research by themselves.
For them, it's much better to give the money to artios.
Who do it better and faster.
And you should know that European automotive industry research is 40% of the overall global research in automotive industry.
USA is less than 20%.
There are several practical proposals on behalf of the Arthur how to fulfill the task.
All of them are really nicely complementary to the framework, but would like to stress most collaboration in the field of advanced technologies.
And this proposal was just finished, is now being modified by the members of the Arthur and the new Commission will face it in the couple of months for sure.
So we hope that the Arthur will be one of the engines pushing forward European coping with the crisis in the field of technology and joining in the.
History and research.
Independent from that, I'm very glad to say that the artist Board meeting in Ljubljana in autumn last year, which was attended also by Commissioner Potocnik and hosted very nicely by our partners.
This time I will be careful.
Yours have Steven Institute.
Also was a place where Arthur Board proposed the idea of Cdr to initiative.

Not just to see her to, but coming out from the fact that Artios in this region could be strong supporters for the other countries in the Southeast Europe who do not have research and technology institutes that have so long tradition in such capacities as do have Austria, Slovenia or Croatia.
So our idea was to use us as friends who could support from both near further South.
Other friends.
The current Commission was not able to find the way how to realize this initiative, and I'm quite sure that this initiative will be one of the next topics for the new Commission as well to fulfill.
This task and we did I hope you have been satisfied with my substituted law instead of Chris Hall, and I thank you for your attention.
As a chair I have to ask, do you have any questions?
If not, then it's a Oh yes please.
What would be a view of how can we are to help the rest of the Western Balkan countries?
Because I I do appreciate the fact that they did.
We have, for example, I was at the meeting with customer delegation, attended.
They don't have a single ground that the government can offer to scientists.
Just give us your kind of perspective how this organization.
Yes, well first thing what I think is quite obvious.
One needs to have human resources and material resources.
They could work together.
You use the example of coastal.
I must say I'm not very familiar with the situation in Kosovo.
I could guess it only how it looks like so certainly.

Certainly there is a lot of problems in both material and human resources, like in case of Croatia and many other countries that were unfortunate experiencing too many wars in too short period of time.
It's certain that there are many experts who are spread worldwild not being present on Kosovo.

While we do have certainly on costs over many of young people who are ambitious and would like to do research and due to the circumstances, I think they would be more interesting applied research than Justin theoretical research for the personal career.

We do have experience we could train these people who could not be trained on Kosovo or by themselves and for whom it may be too difficult, too expensive, too far to do the trainings in even Germany not to speak about the overseas countries.
We do have far less language difficulties and we have better mutual understandings.
Although we do have differences in culture in history, but we do have many things and many good reasons why we should support each other as relatively close neighbors.
Second thing, as you know, the Dubrovnik University is just five years old.
And in this five years it got several PhD study programs.
Which was impossible to imagine at the beginning.

Many of these PhD study programs were based on support of our Institute as a matter of fact, right now in Dubrovnik there are so many PhD students that certainly this University has long lasting perspective and even the local hospital will become a highly respected research institution and it has unlike many other hospitals, in vitro research facilities.
So they could culture human cancer, for example, within the hospital.
That's extraordinary.
The price of that was really reasonable.
Less than 50,000 euros.
And that was done with the help of our Institute.
So there are many ways how we could do it without a lot of money and with only minimal political and financial support.
Of course, like in any other cases without political support, nothing could be done.
That's clear, good friendship.
Under such circumstances need good politicians, but we don't need a lot of money.

Even with the little money we have experienced at our Institute in our country during the days of war, we were able to do a lot, but we had good friends in particular in Austria who have been sending US equipment who have been supporting us in research by many ways, and I'm glad to say that Austria was the first country that set up a program of supporting research on Kosovo, and they have been lateral collaboration projects done in a very smart way.

In the way by inclusion of another country in the region, and we also serve for that purpose, and being in a way very affiliated to Austrian, as an Austrian pupil and having Austrian origin in a way, I'm also glad to say that we all remember SharePoint.
Sony program in early 90s, by which Austria itself was supporting training of students and experienced researchers from Ukraine, Croatia, Slovenia.
When I was in grad.
There have been so many Slovenians Croats on trainings altogether, more than 100, just at a single University paid by Austrian government.
Many of the links exist still as they did at the beginning, so I hope my answer was good enough.
Thank.
